bookCover.coverDescription:
Welcome to Compass, this is all generating awareness of the amazing range of technologies that are available to all students in DCU. The technologies range from tools within your:

  • DCU Goggle student account

  • DCU Microsoft account

  • A tool called Sensus Access

  • and services that impart technology skills to you.

Compass is all about supporting you to navigate these technologies and services so you can settle into your student journey. We'll give you tips about how these DCU technologies can help with:

  • different ways to use technology for reading

  • choices about how you can write an essay with technology

  • Ways to use technology to stay organised.

  • Signposting you to technology-linked services so you can get help and technology skills.

params.text:
Google account

You can create a Google account free. You might already have one if you use Gmail for your personal email. In this account you have many Inclusive Technology possibilities. These possibilities involve how you can read, write, organise and find information and a whole lot more. Let's start to explore them.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

This guide was adapted with permission from Compass, created by Trevor Boland and DCU.

Google Account

Sign in to your Google account or register to create a new one and try some of the inclusive technologies that we will explore here in Compass.

params.title: What is in your Google Account

params.text:
Here, in your Google Drive, is one of the ways you can access all the apps that you get in your Google account. Key applications that you may use will be:

  • Google Docs: Useful for Writing Assignments
  • Google Slides: Great for creating presentations.

params.text: Explore how technology can support diverse people in diverse ways.

Try the Chrome Browser

You can create a Google account free. You might already have one if you use Gmail for your personal email. In this account you have many Inclusive Technology possibilities.. A browser you may use to access your Google account can be Chrome. In Chrome, you can access these Google apps and tools.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

The Chrome Browser

On your computer, try to log into your Chrome Browser to access your Gmail account. Chrome is made by Google, so it works effectively with your DCU Google account. In Chrome, you can now access the following Google online applications:

  • Google Docs for writing documents
  • Google Calendar for organizing your time
  • Google Keep for digital post-it notes
  • Google Slides to create presentations
  • Google Drive to organize and save all your files.
In Chrome, go to the Nine circle icon in the top right to access all your Google applications. When you can see the applications, you can drag them to rearrange them.

l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.

metadata.title: Explore Chrome to find our applications

params.text: Take time to get familiar with your Chrome Browser, especially how you access your Google applications. This is key to you being confident about knowing what is in your Google account and what your Google account can do for you to help you succeed.

Bookmarking in Chrome

When you are in Chrome, you will be exploring many websites over time. You may be looking at websites for your assignments as an example. Keeping track of these useful webpages is key to helping you stay organised. You can make or Bookmark these webpages and store them in a specific place so they can be accessed easily.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

In your Chrome browser, you can see on the top, there are sections where you can type in the URL or web address of a website.

To the right of this is a small star icon.

When you select the star icon, this will bookmark a webpage. Now you can save the save in your Chrome Browser.

Lets make a folder in the browser to keep our bookmarks really organised.

  1. Just under the section where you type your URL, place your cursor under here and right click on it.
  2. This will make a menu appear and select 'Add Folder'.
  3. Name the folder.
  4. Select Bookmarks Bar.
  5. This creates the new folder in your Chrome browser.
  6. Now select the bookmark star, select the folder you wish to save it in.
  7. Then select done.

Try it out and keep organised as you go.

hotspots.header: Creating a folder for my Bookmarks.

params.text: It's good to know what you can find in your Microsoft account.

Your Google account

You can create a Google account free. You might already have one if you use Gmail for your personal email. In this account, you have many Inclusive Technology possibilities. A browser you may use to access your Google account is Chrome.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

Google Docs

On your computer you can open the Chrome browser, log into your Gmail account and then access Google Docs.

Google Docs can be useful for your written assignments, some students even use Google Docs for note-taking in class.

It has all you need for writing like:

  • Font types and font sizes.
  • Ways to format your document
  • Inserting images, diagrams and shapes.

Top Tip: You can download a Google Doc and turn it into a Word Document - just go to 'File' in your Google Doc, then go to 'Download' then go to 'Microsoft Word'.

params.title: What to find in Google Docs

params.text:
In this image there are key items to note in Google docs:

  1. All the formatting options so take time to explore for your assignments.
  2. Also, how to download your Google Doc as a Word document so you can submit it to your Lecturer.

metadata.title: A short video about Google Docs.

params.text: Take time out to explore Google Docs. It is great for writing up assignments, class notes, reports, blogs and even collaborating with your class mates on a group assignment (note the 'Share' button in the top right of the Google Doc).

hotspots.header: More about Google Docs in action

params.text:
Your Google account

You can create a Google account free. You might already have one if you use Gmail for your personal email. In this account, you have many Inclusive Technology possibilities. A browser you may use to access your Google account is Chrome.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

Voice Typing in Google Docs give us all the options of creating our assignments by speaking out loud. This can be useful for many reasons:

  • You may be faster at typing with your voice than your hands
  • If you have handwritten your assignment you can type up your first draft with your voice.
  • Some find it easier to articulate what they want to write if they say it out loud.

params.alt: finding voice typing in the tools tab
params.title: using voice typing

params.text:
How do I find the 'Voice Typing' Tool in Google Docs?

  • When you open Google Docs go to the 'Tools' tab in the menu.
  • Then a menu appears and go down until you see 'Voice Typing.
  • Select 'Voice Typing' - this makes a grey dictation icon appear.
  • Select the grey dictation icon and now it will change colout to red.

(The Chrome Browser may ask you to grant permission to use your microphone - allow this)

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.

l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

metadata.title: How to use Voice typing in Google Docs

params.text:
Try Voice Typing in Google Docs. Open a Doc, activate Voice Typing and test it.

Top Tips:

  • Use a headset with a microphone for best results
  • Try it in a room that doesnt have an echo.
  • Use it in a space with no background noises.
  • Practice as not everyone is comfortable speaking out loud.
  • Trying speaking out the punctuation like 'Full Stop' at the end of every sentence.

hotspots.header: A video about your Microsoft account

params.text:
Spelling and Grammar in Google Docs

Spelling and Grammar tips help us all when it comes to writing assignments. In Google Docs, there is a tool that can help with this very matter.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

Spelling and Grammar

To find the Spelling and Grammar tool in Google Docs is easy.

  • Just go to the main menu on the top of your Google Doc.
  • Then to the tab called 'Tools'.
  • Just go to the option called 'Spelling and Grammar'.
  • Then select from the menu the 3 options.(Spelling or Grammar or both)

Tip: There is an option called 'Personal Dictionary'. This option allows you to add additional words to your dictionary in Google Docs.

hotspots.header: Using the Speling and Grammar support

params.alt: How to find the Spelling and Grammar support
params.title: Spelling and Grammar option

params.text:
Practice using the Spelling and Grammar support in Google Docs. Explore the settings to see what spelling and or grammar options are useful to you.

It is especially good to explore the 'Personal Dictionary' as you will have words that Docs can't recognize so add them as you go.

Top Tip: Also, in the 'Tools' tab you can find an option called 'Dictionary'. Really useful for you to break down your assignment question and to explore new terms in your course.

metadata.title: Google Docs and Spelling and Grammar

params.text:
When you write up your assignment, take time to check the spelling and grammar. Time is needed to craft your work so give it the time it deserves.

The more you use the spelling and grammar support the more effective you will get at using it.

hotspots.header: Using Spelling and Grammar in Docs

params.backgroundImageAltText: Spelling and grammar in Google Docs

metadata.title: Spelling and Grammar in Google Docs?

params.text:
'Reader Mode' - Reading Support for Chrome

Tools that read out text can be a huge benefit to everyone for different reasons. Some of the reasons may involve reading large amounts of text, listening to text can be more effective than reading for some, and others just prefer listening over reading.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

When you are on your computer you may be using your Chrome browser. You can add a tool to your Chrome Browser called 'Reader Mode' and this can read out text in a webpage to you. 

Go to the website, select add 'Reader Mode' to Chrome.

Then activate it in your Chrome browser (go to the tiny black jigsaw icon on the top of your browser - then pin it).

Now you can activate it when you are on the webpage you want to read - just click on the 'Reader Mode' icon in the top browser (three grey horizontal lines).

params.alt: When you add Reader Mode to Chrome you pin it to activate it.
params.title: Pinning 'Reader Mode' to your Chrome browser

params.text:
If this is your first time adding a tool to Chrome, a few tips are needed. The little black jigsaw in Chrome, found on the top.

This reveals the apps you have added to your Chrome browser. There is a pin beside each one.

Select the pin and this makes the 'Reader Mode' icon appear in Chrome.

Now you should be all to see the icon - it is three grey horizontal lines.

When you select the icon, the webpage is simpler to read, and a menu appears in the top right corner. Select the speaker icon and press play to read out the webpage.

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
When you use Reader Mode, it helps in several Ways:

  • It simplifies the webpage so you can read with less distractions.
  • It offers an estimated reader time on the top of the webpage.
  • You can change fonts and font sizes.
  • You can choose different voices to read aloud.

Try it for yourself and experience the ways it can help you.

'Reader Mode' - Reading Support for your Smart Phone

Reading tools on your Smart phone can be a great option - you can then listen to text as you walk, run, commute, or just listen to text if that is your preference.

Tools that read out text can be a huge benefit to everyone for varied reasons. Let's explore this Reading Mode app for your Smart phone.

Note: Reader Mode app is just available for Android phones.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

To use Reading mode, your device must run Android 9 and up. Reading mode currently is only available on Android phones.

  1. On your Android device, open the Google Play Store app
  2. At the top, search for “Reading mode.”
  3. Select the Reading mode app.
  4. Tap Install.
  5. Open the Reading mode app .
  6. Follow instructions in the tutorial. You get redirected to the Accessibility Settings menu.
  7. Tap Reading mode.
  8. Turn on Reading mode shortcut. A prompt displays.
  9. To allow Reading mode permissions, tap Allow.

params.alt: Reader Mode on your Android device
params.title: 'Reader Mode' for your phone

params.text:
Change Reading mode settings

In Reading mode settings, you can change the:

  • Color theme
  • Font size
  • Font type
  • Bold
  • Line space
  • Reading voice
  • Reading speed

l10n.name: Video

metadata.title: Reader Mode for your Android phone

params.text:
When you use Reader Mode, it offers options:

  • When you install it on your phone you activate it via a short cut button on your phone.
  • You must be on a webpage with text for the app to work.
  • it offers an estimated reading time
  • the play button reads the text aloud
  • increase and decrease font size
  • The cog icon reveals more options like reading speed and colour background.

Your Google Calendar

Time management is a key skill to have to plan your day-to-day activities. You Google Calendar can be a big support for this, so taking time out to explore how to use and then make the Calendar fit your needs.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

Tips for Google Calendar

Google calendar is part of your Google account. Go to Chrome, open your Google account and then go to your nine circle icon to pull up your Google account menu and select the calendar.

A starting point could be to take your weekly academic calendar and to add it to your Google Calendar. You can repeat each entry so it can populate your calendar over a number of weeks.

When you are in Google Calendar, click on the time you wish to input into your calendar.

Options will appear such as, to name the entry - give it a name, then, click on 'more options'. Now you can choose to repeat the calendar entry (by default it says 'Doesn't Repeat') by day, week or month.

Explore these options to create your weekly calendar.

Top Tip: Start adding not only your class times but your commute time, Relaxation time and leisure time as well as when you work. This way you get a clearer sense of the time you have to study and to write assignments.

params.text: Get a few tips about how student uses Google Calendar. Always good to see how Calendar can be used and get a few ideas.

Google Keep - Keeping the small things organised

Google Keep is ideal to keep all those small things organised. This can be in the form of to-do lists as one example.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

To get started with Google Keep, you'll need to choose a platform. The Keep Android app is available in the Google Play Store for phones and smartwatches, and iPhone and iPad users will find the Keep app in the App Store. It also works in most web browsers through the desktop app, and there's a Google Keep web clipper extension in the Chrome Web Store.

hotspots.header: Try Google Keep on your devices.

params.title: using Google Keep to help you

params.text:
Make your First Note in Google Keep

Step 1: Create a note

  1. On your computer, go to keep.google.com.
  2. At the top, click Take a note.
  3. Enter your note and click Done.

Step 2: Edit and format

You can edit, organize, and archive notes. Explore all the possibilities with this tool:

  • Make a list 
  • Save a drawing as a note - 
  • Label, color, or pin notes
  • Archive notes & lists
  • Set up reminders for your notes

hotspots.header: What does Google Keep look like?

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
Google Keep is a great way to keep track of all those to-do-lists, to help keep you organised and jot down ideas and tips. Explore Google Keep and see how it can help you to stay on track of the day-to-day things.

Top Tip - You can set reminders in a number of ways:

  1. By date and time so you can get a reminder on a set day.
  2. By location so when you arrive somewhere you will be alerted to do something marked on your Google Keep.

Google Drive - Create and Organise

If you have a Google accoutn who have Google Drive - this is amazing as it does two main functions:

Allows us to organise and store an online back-up of our files like Word, PowerPoint, PDF and more.

Allows us to create content too like Google Docs and Google Slides for work.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

Google Drive

Technology can help you to stay organised, and Google Drive gives you options for this. Consider using Google Drive to:

  • Create and name Folders and sub-folders.
  • Colour Code Folders
  • Prioritise File by select the star icon

Taking the time to find your way to stay organised helps you to order your information for assignments and exams.

params.alt: Tips for Google Drive - on your Google folder, select the three dots, select organise, and now you can colour code your folders.
params.title: Google Drive to help you stay organised

params.text:
When you make a Folder in Google Drive, select the 3 dots on the folder to make a few options appear.

Colour coding is a great way to visually organise in a way that may help.

Explore and find your ways to keep your information organised in a way that makes sense to you.

l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.

params.text:
In this video I show you a few ways to use Google Drive to help organisation skills.

Invest time in developing these skills as they will pay off over time.

Top Tip: Organised files reduce time to find files which is a great skill especially if you need files for assignments and exams.

Your Google Lens

Google Lens is an amazing tool that works on your Smartphone / Tablet (just download it from your app store) and it can be used on your Computer too.

One key ability of Google Lens is reading out text in an image or photo. It does a whole lot more but this guide will just focus on this one feature.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

Try Google Lens.

Google Lens can be used on your Computer or on your smartphone.

In this example, I will explore the Google Lens app. 

  • If you have a book, you can open Google Lens, photograph the page of the book.
  • Select the word 'Text' along the base of the screen.
  • It will scan the text, and now you can select the button called 'Listen'
  • Google Lens will read out the text in the image.

Top Tips:

  1. Google Lens can also copy the text and can translate the text from the image too.
  2. You can get Google Lens to read out text in photos in your photo album too.

Try using your phone to use Google Lens. Think about the situations where you will be reading, how you can use photos of the information you need to read, and when you can listen to the read material.

You could photograph:

  • Articles from your lecturer
  • Books from the library
  • Reports and journals.

hotspots.header: Using Google Lens on your Smartphone.

params.text: It's good to try not only the app version of Google Lens but the Computer version too - that you can open in your Chrome Browser. Explore the possibilities of each and think about the ways it can support your studies.

Making your Google Slides inclusive

When you present your Google Slides, you can activate a feature called closed captions. This has an inclusive feature - as you speak your dialogiue is displayed in the presentation so for people who may have hearing challenges can see your words.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

How do I switch on the Closed Captions feature:

  1. Open your presentation in Google Slides.
  2. To start presenting, go to 'View' and click 'Present'.
  3. To turn on captions, click CC (this is found in the menu at the bottom of your slide when you are in Presenter mode). ...
  4. As you speak, captions appear at the bottom of the screen.
In Google Slides. Select the CC button (Closed Captions) and you can choose the size of the text and where the text will be displayed over the presentation.

hotspots.header: The Closed Captions button in Google Slides

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.

params.text:
Try switching on the CC (Closed Captions) and try the accuracy of the tool in Google Slides. It won't pick up every word perfectly, but it is quite accurate.

Top Tip - the microphone on your laptop / computer will help - a headset improves accuracy.

Making your Google Doc accessible.

The documents in your Google account can be made accessible - this means you can create your document in a way whereby all can access the content. This means that even people who are blind can avail of the information effectively in the document.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

Create Accessible Google Docs

These are steps to create accessible documents in the Google Workspace.

1. Use an Accessibility Checker

An automated accessibility checker can help you spot and fix accessibility errors while you work. The Accessibility Checker for Docs checks your Google Doc against Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).

While automated checkers won’t catch every issue, they are a great tool to have in your tool set and are a good reminder that we should be thinking about accessibility when creating or editing content.

2. Add File Metadata

Add Metadata for your file to clearly identify it to your audience. Give the file a clear title and file name. Identify the language of the document.

How to add Metadata

In your program, modify the displayed file name and navigate to File settings to change the language.

3. Add a Heading Structure

Provide an outline of your document that provides better navigation, thereby improving accessibility. Typically, recommend using only one Heading 1 in your document, but you can use multiple Heading 2, Heading 3. Keep things hierarchical: Don't skip heading levels. Don't go from a Heading 1 to a Heading 5. Read more about identifying headings, lists, and tables.

How to Add Headings

Use the Styles menu option to apply heading levels to section text in your document

4. Format Text for Legibility

Format your text so that it is easier for your audience to read. Consider using a sans serif font, setting line spacing to 1.5. Keep text left-aligned when possible to allow users to easily identify new lines. Keep font at a standard size or larger. For documents, that is 11pt and for slide presentations 18pt.

5. Break Content into Lists, Where Possible

Browse your document to see if any paragraphs would be easier to read as a list. Lists make content easier to read by providing visual structure and highlighting key points.

How to Add Lists

Use the Paragraph Panel to select a bullet or numbered list.

6. Write Descriptive Links

Write link text so that it is unique, descriptive, and clear about where the link goes. If sharing documents for printing, consider including both a descriptive link and the full link text. Find additional guidance: How to Write Helpful Links.

How to Edit Link Text

Select and highlight the text you would like to link. Right click and chose edit link text.

7. Add Alt Text to Images

Add alternative text for all non-decorative images to convey the equivalent information to someone who may not be able to see the image. Keep it short and descriptive, like a tweet. Don’t include “image of” or “photo of”. For some examples, visit this page on alt text.

How to Add Alt Text to Images

In most programs, right-click on an image to bring up a menu with the options "Add Alt Text" or "Edit Image."

8. Use High Colour Contrast

Choose a colour for your text and other elements that has a high degree of contrast against the background colour. For web content, the standard is 4.5:1 for most text. Avoid light text on light backgrounds and dark text on dark backgrounds.

params.alt: Accessibility Checker called Accessibility Checker for Docs. Add it to your Google Docs
params.title: Accessibility in Google Docs

params.text: Google Docs and Slides have an accessibility Checker called Grackle that allows you to check how accessible your content is - add Grackle to your Chrome Browser.

params.text:
Live Transcribe - an app

The Live Transcribe app is free and primarily useful for transcribing a verbal conversation. 

Most useful for: If you are in a conversation with someone who is deaf or hard of hearing then it may be a useful way to transcribe your voice, and they can type a response.

A great website about the app and how it can be used.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

How to use the Live Transcribe app.

  1. Tap the Live Transcribe app.  

  1. Make sure that you're connected to the internet. 

  1. Hold your device microphone near the person or sound that you want to capture. The microphone is usually located at the bottom of your device

  2. Download it and try the app out.

params.title: using Live Transcribe to help you interact

params.text:
You can type your responses too in the app: 

  1. While Live Transcribe is running, tap ‘Type’. 

  1. Enter text using the on-screen keyboard. 

  1. To return to full-screen, tap back.

l10n.name: Video
l10n.noPlayers: Found no video players that supports the given video format.
l10n.unknownYtId: Unable to find video with the given YouTube ID.
l10n.restrictedYt: The owner of this video does not allow it to be embedded.

params.text:
Think about the situation you may have been in or could be in and how this app could help with interacting.

Top Tip for adding more recognisable words to the app:

  1. While Live Transcribe is running, tap Settings (a cog icon). 

  1. Tap More settings. 

  1. Tap Custom words. 

  1. Tap Add word.

YouTube for College Work

If you have a Google account, you will also have a YouTube account. YouTube has so much information, and other than videos about kittens and puppies, it has great videos about many of the types of technology you could come across.

Tip: Select the yellow icons to reveal text or an image or a video

YouTube for your academic needs.

Searching YouTube effectively can be a great asset to your studies.

Consider searching videos about topics like:

  • How to use Word
  • How to use PowerPoint
  • How to use Google Docs
  • How to use Google Slides

When searching for information consider how to phrase your search terms:

  • How do I add page numbers to my Word document
  • Formatting tips for a Google Document

Top Tip: be as detailed as possible when you are searching for information

Keeping your YouTube videos together.

Create a playlist for the videos you find:

  1. At the bottom of each video that you watch there are options
  2. Click More (three dots). Select 'Save'. Create new playlist. Enter a name for the playlist.
  3. Use the box to select your playlist's privacy setting. If it's private, only you can view the playlist.
  4. Click Create.

Now you can gather your videos by topic and save them for easy access later.

metadata.title: A YouTube video about Google Searching

params.text:
There is a bounty of video tutorials in YouTube about how to:

  • How to use Word - formatting, adding page numbers.
  • Creating referencing
  • Adding citations
  • Using all kinds of software

Top Tip: The video has a key message about searching for information online. Be as explicit as possible when it comes to searching for information. This makes a big difference.

hotspots.header: A video about your searching in Google
